Purpose

The purpose of this guideline is to stratify the management of women requesting termination of pregnancy and to ensure that a streamlined approach is taken to maintain safety and support for these women. This will include appropriate pre-operative evaluation, timing of surgery and post-operative care with an emphasis on contraceptive advice and counselling.
Equality Impact Assessment
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.

This pathway will ensure that medical practitioners who object to termination of pregnancy will not be involved in the management of these women and thus the care of these women will not be affected by dissenters to the process.
(Refer to Appendix 5)
Scope

Surgical termination of pregnancy (conventional suction termination – STOP or vaginal termination of pregnancy - VTOP) is suitable for pregnancies between 7 and  weeks. These can be carried out at Broomfield Hospital as a day case.

Medical abortions (from 5 to 9 weeks' gestation) and abortion carried out after  weeks are not performed at Broomfield Hospital and such patients are required to go to Marie Stopes in Buckhurst Hill for use of their services or seek support from the British Pregnancy Advisory Service.
Referral Process

The GPs should initiate an urgent referral letter and every attempt will be made to accommodate these women within 5 days where possible or the nearest available clinic appointment. Mr. Spencer's alternate Monday afternoon clinic is the first choice – failing that Wednesday afternoon Gynaecological Outpatient's Department (GOPD) is an alternative.

In the referral letter, the GP should make the team aware of any existing medical conditions and allergies, and highlight any psychological or social circumstances that may require additional support or attention.

The referring GP, or another GP from the patient's practice, should fill in Part A of the 1967 Abortion Act Form (HSA1), if this is possible, as it can be difficult for the surgical team to find two doctors that are able to complete the certificate. It should be noted that the doctor signing the form does not need to have seen or examined the patient.
Contraception

The GP should discuss future contraception with the patient prior to referral, issue a prescription and specify her choice of method in the referral letter. The aim is that all patients should have a reliable (non-barrier) contraceptive method in place prior to leaving the hospital after a termination of pregnancy. MEHT no longer offers laparoscopic sterilization at the time of vaginal termination of pregnancy.

Practitioners performing surgical terminations will insert coils (either copper or levonorgesterel containing IUDs at the time of vaginal termination of pregnancy, if requested, as long as patients have been counselled about these methods in advance by their GP or Consultant/Specialty Doctor when seen at MEHT.
An injection of Depo-Provera can be given in hospital on the day of the procedure.
Management at Broomfield Hospital Gynaecology Outpatient Clinic

The patient should be seen within 5 days from GP referral, if feasible. The patient should be offered a surgical termination to be carried out within 7 days from the time of the assessment or decision to proceed following clinical assessment, with a view to carrying out the procedure before 9 weeks gestation if at all possible, as it is recognised that the procedure is safer at gestations below 9 weeks.

The patient should be asked for the reasons that led to the wish to have an abortion, so as to enable the surgeon to fill HSA1 (Abortion Act Form) Appendix 3 and HSA4 (Abortion Notification) Appendix 4 following Termination. HSA4 must be completed on line by the Practitioner terminating the pregnancy or if not possible to complete on line it can be sent via mail within  days of the termination to the Department of Health.

The Doctor at Broomfield GOPD should take blood for full blood count (FBC), and Blood Group and Rh factor, if not already known, and make sure the report, or a copy of a previous report from the notes, is available to the surgeon by the time the patient is seen on the day case admissions unit.
If the patient is known to be Rhesus D negative, the doctor should discuss the need for administration of Anti-D immunoglobulin with the patient.
The doctor should consider sexually transmitted infection (STI) testing, for chlamydia, syphilis, HIV, or hepatitis B or C, depending on the patient's sexual and social history.

Routine scanning for gestation is not required if patient's own dates are felt to be reliable and if clinical examination is in agreement with this. In certain situations, ultrasound (transvaginal or abdominal) can be employed if the patient is uncertain of her dates, has a high body mass index making clinical examination inaccurate or there is acute uterine retroversion preventing clinical dating to be properly done.
The patient should be offered a Cervical Smear Test if one is due or overdue.

The doctor should also consent the woman for the termination of pregnancy procedure, write up the appropriate drugs (antibiotics- Doxycycline 100mg, anti-D if needed and misoprostol) in addition to completing the VTE form found in the MEHT drug chart. Please refer to MicroGuide when prescribing the antbiotics.
The patient should be offered information on the risks of the process and these are covered in the patient information leaflet on ‘Termination of Pregnancy'. These risks include:
That there is a risk of haemorrhage of about 1: 1000, lower for early abortions
That there is a risk of uterine perforation, of about 1-4 per 1000
That there is a risk of cervical trauma, less than 1 in
That there is a small risk of bowel perforation of about, 1 in
That abortion can fail, but the risk of this is low, 1-2 per 100 procedures, but
if this occurs then a second procedure may be needed to remove retained products of conception
Post-operative infection can occur, but this risk is reduced by the use of peri- operative antibiotics
That there is no proven association between induced abortion and subsequent ectopic pregnancy, subfertility, breast cancer or placenta praevia.

The patient needs to be informed that she will be admitted to the Day Surgery Unit and be able to go home later in the day if a responsible adult is available at home. 1-2 hours pre-operatively, she will be given a vaginal preparation (Misoprostol 400-800 micrograms), which will soften the cervix and make the procedure easier.
Antibiotics will need to be given please refer to the Trust's MicroGuide available on the intranet
If a patient decided on medical termination or surgical termination for fetal abnormality staff should follow Appendix
(Refer to Flow Chart - Appendix 2)
Management on the Day Surgical Ward

Pre-operatively, the patient's consent form should be checked as well as her blood group type. If the patient wishes an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUD) fitting, this should be included on the consent form. The patient should be advised to see her GP in 6 weeks after IUD fitting to have a thread check. If Depo-Provera is planned, this should be given just before discharge. If the patient is Rhesus D negative, she should receive 250 IU of anti-D IgG within  hours of the procedure, by intramuscular injection into the deltoid muscle just before discharge. (Refer to Administration of Anti D for Rh(D) Negative Patients in Maternity; register number 06065)
The nursing staff should ensure that the patient has signed the ‘disposal of fetal remains' form to ensure that sensitive and appropriate disposal takes place. (Refer Appendix 6 and 7)

When leaving hospital, the patient should have a discharge letter for their GP and analgesic medication to take if required. In addition women should receive a patient information leaflet with instructions about how to care for themselves after they go home including :
How much bleeding to expect in the next few days and weeks
How to recognise potential complications including signs of ongoing pregnancy
When they can resume normal activities (including S.I)
How and where to seek advice if required http://www.meht.nhs.uk/EasysiteWeb/getresource.axd?AssetID=15068&type=full& servicetype=Attachment
Staffing and Training
All nursing and medical staff are to ensure that their knowledge and skills are up to date in order to complete their portfolio for appraisal.
Infection Prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention by ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after each procedure.
All staff should ensure that they follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention. All
invasive devices must be inserted and cared for using high impact intervention guidelines (refer to Saving Lives policy guideline, DoH, 2007) to reduce the risk of infection and
deliver safe care. This care should be recorded in the Saving Lives High Impact
Intervention Monitoring Tool Paperwork (Medical Devices).
Audit and Monitoring

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy (register number 08076), the Corporate Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Project Plan and the Maternity annual audit work plan; to encompass national and local audit and clinical governance identifying key harm themes. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Multi-disciplinary Risk Management Group (MRMG) and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.
The audit report will be reported to the monthly Directorate Governance Meeting (DGM) and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Clinical Governance Group within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Guideline Management

As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.

Quarterly memos are sent to line managers to disseminate to their staff the most currently approved guidelines available via the intranet and clinical guideline folders, located in each designated clinical area.

Guideline monitors have been nominated to each clinical area to ensure a system whereby obsolete guidelines are archived and newly approved guidelines are now downloaded from the intranet and filed appropriately in the guideline folders. ‘Spot checks' are performed on all clinical guidelines quarterly.

Quarterly Clinical Practices group meetings are held to discuss ‘guidelines'. During this meeting the practice development midwife can highlight any areas for further training; possibly involving ‘workshops' or to be included in future ‘skills and drills' mandatory training sessions
Communication

A quarterly ‘maternity newsletter' is issued and available to all staff including an update on the latest ‘guidelines' information such as a list of newly approved guidelines for staff to acknowledge and familiarise themselves with and practice accordingly.
Approved guidelines are published monthly in the Trust's Staff Focus that is sent via email to all staff.
Approved guidelines will be disseminated to appropriate staff quarterly via email.

Regular memos are posted on the Guideline and Audit notice boards in each clinical area to notify staff of the latest revised guidelines and how to access guidelines via the intranet or clinical guideline folders.

Appendix 1
Fetal Abnormality Pathway
Patient requesting termination of pregnancy after chromosomal or structural anomaly diagnosed. Patient seen and counselled by screening midwives +/- fetal medicine consultant

If gestation > 12/40 gestation, Medical Termination and Surgical Termination can be arranged. Medical termination to take place on Gosfield Ward or Labour Ward depending on gestation and patient choice. This will be arranged by Screening Midwife and Waiting List Office. Surgical Termination to be facilitated by the Day Stay Theatre Unit this will be arranged by Screening Midwife and Waiting List Office, women admitted to Gosfield Ward for care before and after Day Stay Theatre care. Certificate A HSA1 (Abortion Act 1967), HSA4 form is to be completed by two Doctors and kept in notes. Consent form and medication written up.

Patient details entered into Screening Midwives' database (‘Rose Cottage' ) HSA4 form ( Abortion Notification) commenced and kept in patient notes, Maternity Secretaries informed of patients details and date of admission to follow up and check HSA4 forms are completed and sent within the recommended timeframe.
Medical and Surgical TOP : Patients notes to be collected by Maternity/Gynaecology Admin
HSA4 form (Abortion Notification) sent to Department of Health within 14 days of termination by Maternity/ Gynaecology Admin
Database for completion of HSA4 forms ( Abortion Notification) updated by maternity secretaries being informed by Screening Midwives following Medical Terminations.
Appendix 2
Gynaecology Outpatients' Pathway
Patient seen in Gynaecology Outpatients requesting Surgical Termination of Pregnancy
History/ pelvic exam +/- ultrasound, bloods (FBC/ Rhesus status), Cervical smear Certificate A (HSA1)completed by two doctors, form stays in notes
Contraception discussed. Antibiotics prescribed and VTE form completed. Anti-D written on drug chart if patient is Rh negative
Date given for Surgical Termination of Pregnancy Patient given information leaflet. Consent form signed by patient
Termination of Pregnancy procedure performed as a day case.
HSA4 form ( Abortion Notification )sent to Departmental of Health by Maternity /Gynaecology Admin
Database for HSA4 completed by Maternity/Gynaecology Admin
